title: Perceived Neighborhood Safety and Active Transportation in Adults from Eight Latin American Countries
Aim: Examine associations between perceived neighborhood safety indicators and domain-specific active transportation.
location: 8 Latin American countries (AR, BR, CL, CO, CR, EC, PE, and VE)
cycling: Cycling participation (people who cycled 10 or more min/week) and cycling duration (min/week cycling)
result: The odds of cycling participation and duration is not higher in participants who agreed that streets were well lit.

title: Effect of Ambient Light on the Number of Motorized Vehicles, Cyclists, and Pedestrians
Aim: Investigate the effect of ambient light level on traffic flow for different types of road user.
result: Darkness leads to significant reductions in pedestrians and cyclists but does not have a significant effect on the number of motorized vehicles.

title: Environmental correlates of dock-less shared bicycle trip origins and destinations
Aim: Examine associations between environmental conditions and dock-less bicycle uptake and deposit
cycling: Dock-less shared bicycle uptake and deposit
result: Street lighting is positively associated with dock-less shared bicycle uptake and deposit.

title: Road lighting density and brightness linked with increased cycling rates after-dark
Aim: Explore whether road lighting can reduce the negative impact of darkness on cycling rates
result: A non linear relationship was found between relative brightness at a location at night and the reduction in cyclists after-dark.

title: Analysis of the impact of street-scale built environment design near metro stations on pedestrian and cyclist road segment choice: A stated choice experiment
Aim: NO INCLUDED REASON: specific near metro stations and quality study
result: Cyclists prefer lamps between 15 m and 30 m.

title: Bicycle facilities safest from crime and crashes: Perceptions of residents familiar with higher crime/lower income neighborhoods in Boston
Aim: NO INCLUDED REASON: on crime and crashes rather than travel behaviour

title: A GPS data-based analysis of built environment influences on bicyclist route preferences
Aim: Examine the effects of built environment on cyclists’route preference
lighting: Number of street lights per mile in 50-ft buffers
analytical_tool: Route choice modelling and mixed logistic regression models
Unit of analysis: Road segment for quantifying the BE, route for discrete choice modeling
result: Some cyclists favor routes which are installed with street lights.

title: Using the daylight savings clock change to show ambient light conditions significantly influence active travel
Aim: Investigate whether ambient light conditions affect the number of people who choose to walk or cycle
result: The numbers of pedestrians (+62%) and cyclists (+38%) were significantly higher during daylight conditions than after-dark.

title: Estimating welfare change associated with improvements in urban bicycling facilities
Aim: Estimate welfare change as willingness to pay for improvements in bicycling facilities
lighting: Presence of lighting in dark time trips
analytical_tool: A stated preference survey was created and a random utility model was used to estimate willingness to pay including street lighting
result: Cycle tracks were valued the most, followed by street lighting and bicycle lanes.

title: Do All Roadway Users Want the Same Things?
Aim: Explore design preferences that could increase perceived traffic safety, walkability, bikeability, and economic vitality along urban arterials.
cycling: Randomly intercept participants on foot or bicycle at eight sites along the study corridor
lighting: Types of street improvements they thought would improve traffic safety.
result: Increasing street lighting is the second top suggestions for cyclists to improve safety.

title: Neighbourhood design and physical activity
Aim: Examine if neighbourhood environments are associated with physical activity, especially walking and cycling
result: Good lighting at night is an important facilitator of cycling.

title: Identification of factors that influence cyclistś route choice
Aim: Evaluate the perception of factors that might influence cycle route choice
result: Street lighting and security are two of the main factors (5 and 6 out of 18) for cycle commuting routes after 1) number of trucks 2) buses and 3) traffic volume and 4) speed.

title: Longitudinal associations between built environment characteristics and changes in active commuting
Aim: NO INCLUDED REASON: it fails to separate walking and cycling
result: Those living in neighbourhoods with more streetlights were more likely to take up active commuting.

title: A whole-year approach showing that ambient light level influences walking and cycling
Aim: Investigate the reactions to changes in lighting from people who walk or cycle
result: More people cycle on cycle trails and walk on foot paths after dark when they are lit than when they are unlit.

title: Route choice of cyclists in Zurich
Aim: NO INCLUDED REASON: 2 studies mention that this paper found street lighting as essential to increase the sense of security for cyclists. However, I could not find such statement in the study

title: Influence of Individual Perceptions and Bicycle Infrastructure on Decision to Bike
Cycling, the Built Environment, and Health: Results of aMidwestern Study
Motivators and deterrents ofbicycling: comparinginfluences on decisions toride
Aim: Evaluate motivators and deterrents of cycling
result: If the route is not well lit after-dark is a major deterrent to cycling, especially for potential cyclists.

title: Factors associated with bicycle ownership and use: A study of six small US cities
Travel demand and the 3Ds: Density, diversity, and design
Aim: NO INCLUDED REASON: it referes to non-automobile travel not specifically to cycling.

title: Cycling and the built environment, a US perspective
Walking, bicycling, and urban landscapes: evidence from the San Francisco Bay area
